text: 12 adaptive radiation that produced the
mighty whale his hands of turn two
flippers and he has a fishy tale
selections made him streamline for his
liquid habitat why didn't I think of
that well I'm Richard Milner I'm known
as the singing Darwinian scholar I've
spent many years studying the life and
times of Charles Darwin but what sort of
sets me off from other Darwin scholars
is that while many of them look only for
intellectual insights when they go
through the history of science I look
for song cues I look for moments in the
history that would be appropriate for a
musical theatre there are fossils in the
ground protozoa in the see all these
unrelated facts made a monkey out of me
now I see how species were selectively
defined I became interested in Darwin
when I was a small kid I was I loved
animals used to go to the Bronx Zoo the
American Museum of Natural History if
you're interested in natural history and
animals you start to wonder where they
all came from and where we came from
pretty soon you're a Darwin's doorstep
but I found him a very engaging
character over the years you know he's a
very large character you have young
Darwin the Explorer you have old door
with the sage and philosopher the
seasick sailor the medical student who
couldn't stand the sight of blood and
left medical school to be a theologian
he was creationist he was a studying for
the clergy but he said he was born the
naturalist and his real life began when
he went aboard HMS Beagle on a five-year
voyage of discovery round the world
after 10,000 miles the Galapagos Isles
now on tents and exceedingly weary but I
feel that this place will dissolve the
disgrace when I use it to further my
theory my scramble is short and the sea
lions roar then I hear a contemptuous
snicker I glanced up in a tree and there
what do I see 17 I started writing songs
in graduate school when I went to the
University of California as an
anthropologist in the early Paleolithic
days and and
then I continued writing songs about
Darwin and evolution over decades and
when i first started giving lectures on
Darwin back in the early 90s at colleges
when the one professor said once you do
some of your songs for the for the
students and I said I didn't think it
was appropriate and they said well after
the show do a few songs and they liked
it so I started doing it more the songs
got bigger the lecture got smaller and
the show may I say evolved there was an
ancient monkey with a long and curly
tail his eight evolved into a man he's
teaching now at Yale a chimp could pass
for up a class in blood and acrobats to
take an interest in intellectual
interest like Darwin and then translated
into musical theatre this is heaven for
me I mean and then I realize other
people who aren't doing this maybe other
people can't do it so that's why I
should do it because I don't want to do
something that everybody else can do and
I've been very fortunate I've been
played my show all over the world
including in the Galapagos Islands on a
cruise ship recently and you know they
had a little sideshow and when I was
finished with my show everybody rushed
out on deck and they had lights on and
the insects were attracted to the lights
and the flying fish were attracted to
the insects and the seals were coming
after the flying fish so that was the
second act
